title: Today's NYT Strands Hints (and Answer) for Wednesday, September 3, 2025
description: If you’re looking for hints and answers for Wednesday, September 3, 2025 with the theme “That’s so sweet!” read on.
content:
If you’re looking for hints and answers for Strands for Wednesday, September 3, 2025, read on—I’ll share some clues and tips, and finally the solution to the puzzle with the theme “That’s so sweet!”

For an easy way to come back to our Strands hints every day, . You can also find our past hints there as well, in case you want to know what you missed in a previous puzzle. (If you play , , or , check out our hints for those games, too.)

Below, I’ll give you some oblique hints at today’s Strands answers. And farther down the page, I’ll reveal the spangram and the answers. Scroll slowly and take just the hints you need!

Hint for the spangram in today’s Strands puzzle

How you might describe an overly sweet drink, like Kool-Aid or a milkshake.

Hint for the theme words in today’s Strands puzzle

We’re about to give away the answers to today’s Strands puzzle.

What is the spangram in today’s Strands?

What are the theme words in today’s Strands?

Here’s what the board looks like when the puzzle is solved:

I assume today’s puzzle will feature sweet treats, like candy, cakes, etc.

I see the word GRANULATED across the bottom of the puzzle. 🔵 That’s a type of sugar, so I guess that’s the theme today: forms of sugar.

I see SUGARY across the center, which is the spangram. 🟡

BROWN is near the bottom right edge. 🔵

What is this letter grouping to the left of BROWN? TREVNI? VERTIN? TINVER? Oh, it’s INVERT, a form of sugar I’ve never heard of . 🔵 I guess it’s a kind of syrup?

POWDERED is along the top of the spangram. 🔵

CUBE is in the upper left corner. 🔵

Lastly, TURBINADO, which I think is the same thing as “raw” sugar. 🔵

You can find the Strands game on the New York Times website and in the NYT Games app.

When you start playing, you’ll see a game board with an assortment of letters, flanked by a clue that gives a hint at the board’s theme—this will be a phrase, like “Better with age.” Your job is to find the hidden words within the board that reflect the puzzle’s theme.

The most important word to find is the “spangram,” a word that more explicitly states the puzzle’s theme. (For example, the spangram for the puzzle with the theme "Better with age" is FERMENTED, which describes products that are, you guessed it, better with age.) The spangram will span the entire game board, either from left to right or top to bottom (hence the name). When you find the spangram, it will be highlighted in yellow. Solving the spangram usually makes the rest of the puzzle much easier to complete.

In Strands, words can travel any direction (up, down, left, right, and diagonal), and you will only use each letter once. There is only one correct solution. When you correctly identify one of the puzzle’s words (for example, KOMBUCHA, MISO, or KIMCHI), it will be highlighted in blue.

If you are struggling to solve the puzzle, you can submit any non-theme words you see (as long as they are four letters or more) to receive credit toward a single hint. If you submit three non-theme words, the “Hint” button will be clickable; if you click it, all of the letters in one of the theme words will be highlighted for you. You will still have to link these highlighted letters in the right order to form one of the theme words. If there is already a hint on the board and you use another hint before solving for that word, that word’s letter order will be revealed.

Unlike Connections and Wordle, you cannot fail Strands. When you submit guesses, you will either correctly identify an answer, receive credit toward a hint, or the text will shake back and forth, indicating that the word you submitted is too short or not valid. You can't run out of guesses, and there is no time limit.

You win when you’ve correctly used all the letters on the board, meaning that you have identified the spangram and all of the theme words. Like other NYT games, upon solving the puzzle, you will see a shareable card that indicates how you performed that day: blue dots 🔵 indicate theme words you found, the yellow dot 🟡 indicates when you found the spangram, and a lightbulb 💡 indicates words that you received a hint for.

Not the day you're after? Here's the solution to yesterday's Strands.
summary: The New York Times has published a list of hints and answers for its Strands puzzle for Wednesday, September 3, 2025. The most important word to find is the "spangram," a word that more explicitly states the puzzle's theme. The spangram will span the entire game board, either from left to right or top to bottom. If you are struggling to solve the puzzle, submit any non-theme words (as long as they are four letters or more) to receive credit towards a single answer. The game can only be played on the New York The Times website and in the NYT Games app.

Invert sugar is frequently used to sweeten and improve the quality of a variety of commercial and homemade confections.
You may wonder what invert sugar is and how it differs from regular table sugar.
This article explores everything you need to know about invert sugar, including what it is, how it’s made, and how it’s used.
Invert sugar — also known as invert sugar syrup or invert syrup — is a liquid sweetener made from granulated table sugar and water.
Table sugar is a compound scientifically known as sucrose. It’s formed when one sugar molecule called glucose chemically binds to another sugar molecule called fructose (
Invert sugar is created via hydrolysis, a process in which sucrose is mixed with water and heated until the bonds between glucose and fructose break. Enzymes or acidic ingredients like citric acid or cream of tartar can be added to expedite the process (2).
The result is a thick, sweet syrup comprised of half glucose and half fructose (2).
Because fructose is the sweetest type of natural sugar, the presence of free fructose in invert sugar gives it a much sweeter flavor compared with regular table sugar (
Why is it called invert sugar?
Invert sugar earned its name from its unique light-reflective properties.
The presence or absence of chemical bonds between sugar molecules can alter the direction in which light is reflected as it passes through them.
When polarized light passes through regular table sugar (sucrose), it’s always reflected in a certain direction. When the same light passes through invert sugar, it reflects in the opposite — or inverted — direction. Hence, it’s called invert sugar.
SummaryInvert sugar is a liquified form of table sugar in which the chemical bonds between glucose and fructose molecules have been broken.
Invert sugar’s primary function is to sweeten foods and beverages, but it also comes with several functional benefits.
It helps baked goods retain moisture and improves texture by preventing crystallization, which can occur when using regular table sugar.
If you’ve ever tried adding granulated sugar to a cold beverage like iced tea or coffee, you’ve likely noticed that sugar crystals don’t readily dissolve.
Invert sugar gives more a uniform sweetness and mitigates the problem of sugar crystals collecting in the bottom of your glass, as it’s considerably more water-soluble than regular sugar.
Invert sugar can be used in combination with other sweeteners to sweeten a variety of common foods, such as:
- ice cream
- sorbet
- gelato
- jellies
- fudge
- ganache
- taffy
- soft-baked cookies
- cakes
- frozen cocktails and other iced beverages
- flavored syrups
Invert sugar is also frequently used to ferment products like beer and kombucha.
Fully inverted sugar contains around 50% glucose and 50% fructose, but you can purchase or make it with varying concentrations of glucose, fructose, and sucrose depending on how long it’s heated.
Commercially prepared invert sugar is arguably the most convenient and chemically precise option, but it’s not always available in regular grocery stores.
If your local grocery store doesn’t carry it, you may have better luck finding it online or in specialty restaurants or bakery supply shops.
How to make invert sugar at home
Although it may sound daunting, making invert sugar at home isn’t complicated. The process takes a little over an hour and all you need is water, sugar, cream of tartar, and a candy thermometer.
Start by mixing 2 cups (480 mL) of water with 4.4 cups (1 kg) of granulated sugar and 1/4 teaspoon of cream of tartar in a pot. Bring the mixture to a boil over medium heat until it reaches 236°F (114°C), stirring occasionally.
Next, remove the mixture from the heat, cover, and let cool. Once it’s cool enough to handle, transfer it to a jar and store it in your refrigerator for up to 6 months.
SummaryInvert sugar sweetens foods like cakes, ice cream, and candy while helping them maintain a smooth texture and improving moisture retention.
Invert sugar is a form of added sugar, and its nutritional features are almost identical to those of regular table sugar or corn syrup.
Invert sugar contains about 46 calories and 13 grams of sugar per tablespoon (15 mL) (
It’s important to limit your intake of foods that contain invert sugar. Overconsumption of any type of added sugar is associated with an increased risk of chronic conditions like heart disease, diabetes, liver disease, and obesity (
Although added sugar can be safely consumed in moderation, the American Heart Association recommends limiting your intake to no more than 6 teaspoons (25 grams per day) for women and 9 teaspoons (37.5 grams) per day for men (
Simply treat invert sugar like any other form of added sugar and aim to avoid consuming too much to reduce your risk of experiencing adverse health outcomes.
SummaryInvert sugar is a form of added sugar and overconsumption could lead to negative health effects.
Invert sugar is a liquid sweetener made from table sugar (sucrose) and water.
It’s formed when the bonds between the sugars in sucrose are broken, resulting in a thick, sweet syrup comprised of 50% fructose and 50% glucose.
Invert sugar adds sweetness and helps improve moisture retention and quality in a variety of sweets like ice cream, cakes, cookies, and candy.
Nutritionally, invert sugar is similar to any other type of added sugar like table sugar or corn syrup. You should consume it sparingly, as consuming too much may contribute to negative health outcomes.
If you’re interested in trying invert sugar, you can purchase it online or try making it at home.

If you’re looking for hints and answers for Strands for Tuesday, September 2, 2025, read on—I’ll share some clues and tips, and finally the solution to the puzzle with the theme “Things are starting to take shape.”
For an easy way to come back to our Strands hints every day, bookmark this page. You can also find our past hints there as well, in case you want to know what you missed in a previous puzzle. (If you play Wordle, Connections, or Quordle, check out our hints for those games, too.)
Below, I’ll give you some oblique hints at today’s Strands answers. And farther down the page, I’ll reveal the spangram and the answers. Scroll slowly and take just the hints you need!
Hint for the spangram in today’s Strands puzzle
School subject for shapes.
Hint for the theme words in today’s Strands puzzle
Specific shapes and terms learned in this specialized type of math.
BEWARE: Spoilers follow for today’s Strands puzzle!
We’re about to give away the answers to today’s Strands puzzle.
What is the spangram in today’s Strands?
Today’s spangram is GEOMETRYCLASS.
What are the theme words in today’s Strands?
The theme words today are: ANGLE, POINT, CIRCLE, LINE, AREA, VOLUME, PLANE.
Here’s what the board looks like when the puzzle is solved:
How I solved today’s Strands
I’ll start looking for shape and geometry words.
There’s ANGLE in the upper left. 🔵
I see GEOMETRY to the right of that, which is probably the start of the spangram. Yeah, it’s GEOMETRYCLASS. 🟡
CIRCLE is in the bottom left. 🔵
POINT finishes the left half. 🔵
LINE is in the upper right. 🔵
VOLUME is in the center, along the right edge. 🔵
PLANE is in the bottom right corner. 🔵
Lastly, AREA. 🔵
Strands #548 “Things are starting to take shape” 🔵🟡🔵🔵 🔵🔵🔵🔵
How to play Strands
You can find the Strands game on the New York Times website and in the NYT Games app.
When you start playing, you’ll see a game board with an assortment of letters, flanked by a clue that gives a hint at the board’s theme—this will be a phrase, like “Better with age.” Your job is to find the hidden words within the board that reflect the puzzle’s theme.
A crossword crossed with a word search
The most important word to find is the “spangram,” a word that more explicitly states the puzzle’s theme. (For example, the spangram for the puzzle with the theme "Better with age" is FERMENTED, which describes products that are, you guessed it, better with age.) The spangram will span the entire game board, either from left to right or top to bottom (hence the name). When you find the spangram, it will be highlighted in yellow. Solving the spangram usually makes the rest of the puzzle much easier to complete.
In Strands, words can travel any direction (up, down, left, right, and diagonal), and you will only use each letter once. There is only one correct solution. When you correctly identify one of the puzzle’s words (for example, KOMBUCHA, MISO, or KIMCHI), it will be highlighted in blue.
If you are struggling to solve the puzzle, you can submit any non-theme words you see (as long as they are four letters or more) to receive credit toward a single hint. If you submit three non-theme words, the “Hint” button will be clickable; if you click it, all of the letters in one of the theme words will be highlighted for you. You will still have to link these highlighted letters in the right order to form one of the theme words. If there is already a hint on the board and you use another hint before solving for that word, that word’s letter order will be revealed.
How to win Strands
Unlike Connections and Wordle, you cannot fail Strands. When you submit guesses, you will either correctly identify an answer, receive credit toward a hint, or the text will shake back and forth, indicating that the word you submitted is too short or not valid. You can't run out of guesses, and there is no time limit.
You win when you’ve correctly used all the letters on the board, meaning that you have identified the spangram and all of the theme words. Like other NYT games, upon solving the puzzle, you will see a shareable card that indicates how you performed that day: blue dots 🔵 indicate theme words you found, the yellow dot 🟡 indicates when you found the spangram, and a lightbulb 💡 indicates words that you received a hint for.
Not the day you're after? Here's the solution to today's Strands.

argos_summary: The article provides hints and solutions for the NYT Strands puzzle on September 3, 2025, themed “That’s so sweet!” The spangram is SUGARY, and theme words include various forms of sugar such as GRANULATED, BROWN, INVERT, POWDERED, CUBE, and TURBINADO. It explains how invert sugar is made and its uses in food and beverages. The piece also references related NYT game hints and includes links to other puzzle solutions.
